Graphical abstract In this work we analyze the photocatalytic performance of Mn+ (MCu, Ni, Zn, Mn) - g-C3N4 materials in toluene photo-oxidation under UV and Sunlight-type illumination conditions. The characterization of the solids showed that Cu and Mn containing samples have an oxide type environment, while Ni has a hydroxide type and Zn shows an oxynitride type local order. The photo-activity of the samples under UV and sunlight excitation(s) was evaluated in terms of activity and selectivity, and the subsequent calculation of the quantum efficiency. Optimum activity was obtained with the Zn-containing catalyst. The charge carrier(s) handling and fate through interfaces and recombination was measured and correlated with the structural characterization of the solids. This indicates that the interface contact between the Zn oxynitride and carbon nitride components has significant influence in charge carrier processes and it is at the core of the good photocatalytic properties owned by this sample. Keywords Carbon nitride Oxide hydroxide Oxynitride Sunlight 1 Introduction Pollution related problems coming from human activities have raised public awareness about the need of creating efficient ways of controlling industrial and mobility originated pollutants. In this context, much attention has been focused on novel advanced oxidation processes. Heterogeneous photocatalysis is one advanced oxidation process that uses semiconductors and light to control and reduce pollution [1–4]. Photocatalysis most significant advantage with respect to other remediation technologies could be the use of the solar energy, a free and renewable energy source. Thus, an urgent need for developing semiconductors effective under sunlight illumination has become evident. One of the materials potentially interesting for sunlight-driven photocatalytic applications is the graphite like carbon nitride (g-C3N4). Graphitic carbon nitride consists on a graphite like structure of tris-z-triazine layers connected through amino groups. As discussed in review articles, g-C3N4 good electronic and chemical properties and thermal stability have allowed the use of the g-C3N4 material as a free metal catalysis for many photochemical reactions such as organic photodegradation, water splitting or alcohol reforming [5–16]. In order to optimize the g-C3N4 catalytic properties for target-specific applications, several modifications of bare g-C3N4 have been conducted. As the charge carrier recombination seems a key property to be improved in g-C3N4, the use of Mn+-promoted systems which can handle charge efficiently has been commonly pursued [5–13]. Systems analyzed in the literature include the surface modification using metals such as Ag, Au, Pt [17–27], or different oxides or hydroxides, among which TiO2 was extensively studied [28–37]. Alternative oxo-hydroxides to TiO2 are typically used in a lower molar content (than titania) in the corresponding binary system with g-C3N4, and catalysts including Ce, W, Cu, Ni, Bi, Zn, In, Mn and others have been considered in the literature [38–45]. Among these oxides we selected two with typical activity in the visible region, Cu and Ni. The corresponding systems would facilitate and improve the utilization of visible light by the g-C3N4-based catalytic powder [38,46,47]. The two other (Zn, Mn) provide, in first place, a significant activity boosting in degradation reactions for g-C3N4-based materials [44,48–51]. In any case, all of the above mentioned Mn+ - g-C3N4 combinations can render, according to literature sources, active systems for solar-assisted photocatalytic oxidation reactions [38,44–51]. An important point is the relative lack of information concerning the nanostructured Mn+-containing component in the catalysts and how it can interact with the support. This is a direct consequence of the relatively low content at which they are present in g-C3N4 based materials. Using thus four Mn+-g-C3N4 (MCu, Ni, Zn, Mn; hereafter called M/g-C3N4 for simplicity) powders we studied the structural and electronic details of the components as well as details of the interaction between components with the help of a multitechnique approach. The results concerning structural and electronic properties of the solids were used to rationalize the catalytic performance of the materials in toluene photo-elimination. Toluene is a typical urban contaminant and corresponds to a though still frequently used test concerning photo-elimination of organic pollutants [52,53]. Here we will measure catalytic performance in quantitative basis through the calculation of the true quantum efficiency. According to the IUPAC recommendations the calculation of the true quantum efficiency requires the modelling of the light-matter interaction in the reactor where catalytic measurements are carried out [54]. Using this approach, the manuscript provides a way to improve the photoactivity of g-C3N4 using supported phases through the seeting up of an intimate link between the catalyst´s components. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Samples preparation The graphitic carbon nitride was obtained by calcination of melamine (Aldrich), in a semi-closed system to prevent sublimation, at 580 °C for 4 h using a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 [55,56]. The g-C3N4 component modified with copper, nickel, zinc and manganese was prepared using an impregnation method. For this, the g-C3N4 and M precursor (copper(II) nitrate hydrate, nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate, zinc(II) nitrate tetrahydrate, manganese(II) nitrate tetrahydrate, Aldrich) were added to a deionized water solution. After 2 h under magnetic stirring the liquid was evaporated at 110 °C and the solid was rinsed with distilled water and dried at 110 °C for 15 h. The final M- g-C3N4 based solids were obtained by calcination at 300 °C, with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 maintaining this temperature for 2 h. Mn+ loading was in all cases ca. 2 wt. % (see below), confirmed with an error below 3.5 % using ICP-AES (induced couple plasma atomic emission spectroscopy measured using a Optima 3300DV Perkin Elmer spectrometer) spectrometry. Samples names are g-C3N4 or M/g-C3N4 with M equal to Cu, Ni, Zn and Mn. 2.2 Characterization methods The BET surface areas and average pore volumes and sizes were measured by nitrogen physisorption (Micromeritics ASAP 2010). XRD profiles were obtained using a Seifert D-500 diffractometer using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation with a 0.02° step. The particle sizes and strain were estimated using XRD using the Williamson–Hall formalism [57]. UV–vis diffuse-reflectance spectroscopy experiments were performed on a Shimadzu UV2100 apparatus using nylon as a reference and the results presented as Kubelka-Munk transform [58]. Photoluminescence spectra were measured at room temperature on a Fluorescence Spectrophotometer (Perkin Elmer LS50B). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out using a JEOL-3000 microscope, operating at 300 kV (Cs 0.6 mm, resolution 1.7 Å). Images were recorded using a CCD camera (model Keen view, SIS analyses size 1024 × 1024, pixel size 23.5 mm × 23.5 mm) at 30000x and 60000x magnification using a low-dose condition. The system has an ADF Gatam detector for X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (XEDS) XPS data were recorded on 4 × 4 mm2 pellets, 0.5 mm thick, prepared by slightly pressing the powered materials which were outgassed in the prechamber of the instrument at room temperature up to a pressure <2 × 10−8 Torr to remove chemisorbed water from their surfaces. The SPECS spectrometer main chamber, working at a pressure < 10−9 Torr, was equipped with a PHOIBOS 150 multichannel hemispherical electron analyzer with a dual X-ray source working with Ag Kα (hv = 1486.2 eV) at 120 W, 20 mA using C 1s as energy reference (284.6 eV). Surface chemical compositions were estimated from XP-spectra, by calculating the integral of each peak after subtraction of the “S-shaped” Shirley-type background [59] using the appropriate experimental sensitivity factors and the CASA-XPS (version 2.3.15) software. The spectra for XANES and EXAFS analyses were recorded at the beamline XAFS2 at the LNLS synchrotron (Campinas, SP, Brazil). The data were obtained in transmission for samples prepared as membranes, using a double crystal Si(111) monochromator and ionization chambers filled at appropriate N2-gas pressure to optimize the counting with simultaneous recording of the metal reference spectrum. The data were analyzed using the IFEFFIT [60], FEFF [61] and XANDA&VIPER [62] codes by standard procedures. For XANES normalization we use the Athena program (standard RBKG, pre-edge and post-edge; see ref. [63]) and we test this standardization with the XANDA program (Victoreen pre-edge, normalization to unity via post-edge, and subtraction the base line generated by smoothing-spline for the pre-peaks isolation). Selected XANES spectra were simulated using the FDMNES code [64]. This code features mono-electronic calculations, which are carried out in the real space, using clusters built around each non-equivalent absorbing atom. In the FDMNES code, two methods are available to calculate the final states: the Multiple Scattering theory (MS) and the Finite Difference Method (FDM). Contrary to the MS method, which relies on the Muffin-tin approximation, the FDM is a full potential method that does not introduce any approximation on the shape of the potential. In the present study we have used the MS and FDM for calculations of Zn K edge in a model structure [65]. A convolution procedure was applied to all calculated spectra to take into account the core hole lifetime and other multielectronic phenomena occurring in the absorption process. At the Fermi level, the Lorentzian (FHWM) width is due to the interaction with the core hole and takes a value of 1.67 eV at the Zn K edge [66]. EXAFS-signal processing considers the extraction of the corresponding signal from the absorption spectrum and the subsequent fitting as detailed in the supporting information section. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were performed with a Bruker ER200D spectrometer operating in the X-band. The sample suspensions (0.5 mg mL−1) were prepared in redistilled water (Milli Q) or methanol (HPLC grade, Scharlab) and sonicated for 4 min. before the experiment. The 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO, Sigma-Aldrich) was used as spin trapping agent. The solutions of DMPO (0.01 M) were prepared in specific solvents (water or methanol) and kept on ice during the whole set of experiments. 100 μL of the solid suspension and 100 μL of the corresponding DMPO solution (in water or methanol) were mixed into an EPR flat quartz cell under atmospheric air. Then the cell containing the experimental mixture (sample/DMPO/water or sample/DMPO/methanol) was irradiated at different times (from 0.5–10 min.) with the identical light excitation source to that employed for the photoreactor (see below), being then immediately transferred to the spectrometer cavity for EPR analysis. In some cases, small radical concentration decay (below 3 % on average) was observed in the dark during the course of spectrum recording. Typical EPR spectrometer settings in a standard experiment were: ca. 9.75 GHz microwave frequency, 19.5 mW microwave power, 100 kHz modulation frequency, 1 G modulation amplitude and 2 × 105 spectrometer gain. All spectra were obtained at room temperature. No significant signal saturation was observed in those conditions. Blank experiments (without sample) were also performed to check the absence of radical formation in DMPO solutions (water or methanol) under irradiation and in the absence of solid. The g-values (±0.0001) were determined using the 2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH, Sigma-Aldrich) as internal standard. The EPR spectra were recorded and analyzed using the Bruker software WinEPR. 2.3 Photo-catalytic experimental details Gas-phase photo-oxidation of toluene (≥99 % Aldrich) was carried in a continuous flow annular photoreactor containing ca. 0.4 mg cm−2 of photocatalyst as a thin layer coating on a pyrex tube. The reactor details are fully described in a previous work and a scheme of it is presented in Fig. S1 [67]. The reacting mixture (100 ml min-1) was prepared by injecting toluene into a wet (ca. 75 % relative humidity) 20 vol.% O2/N2 flow before entering to the photoreactor, yielding an organic inlet concentration of ca. 700 ppmv. Fluorescent UV (Sylvania F6 WBLT-65; 6 W) and sunlight-type lamps (Sylvania F6 W/D; 6 W) were used for the photoreaction experiment. An average photon flux of 1.93/4.38 × 10-3 Einstein cm−2 s-1 was determined inside the reactor for UV/Sunlight-type illumination. Reaction rates and selectivity were evaluated under steady-state conditions, typically achieved after ca. 2 h from the irradiation starting. Selectivity is presented as molar % of carbon containing products. Carbon balance is better than 95.1 % in all cases. The concentration of toluene and the reaction products were analyzed using an on-line gas chromatograph (Agilent GC 6890) equipped with a TCD (for CO2 measurement) and FID (organics measurement) detectors. 2.4 Light-matter interaction modelling and quantum efficiency calculation 2.4.1 Local superficial rate of photon absorption The local superficial rate of photon absorption ( e a , s ) is defined by Eq. (1) [54,67]. In this equation F A s is the fraction of light absorbed by the sample and q s u p the radiation flux at each position ( x _ ≡ X s , Y s , Z s ) of the catalytic film (See Fig. S1). (1) e a , s x _ = q s u p ( x _ ) F A s To obtain the radiation flow on the surface of the samples, we calculate first the impinging radiation flux from the lamps ( q n in Fig. S1). Considering the coordinate system presented in Fig. 1 and the geometry of the reactor (annular multilamp), the q n can be determined by Eq. (2) [67]. (2) q n X s , Y s , Z s = ∑ L = 1 L = 4 ∑ λ ∫ φ m i n , L x , y φ max , L x , y ∫ Ѳ m i n x , y , φ Ѳ m a x x , y , φ P λ , L 2 π R L Z L s i n 2 Ѳ X s - X L R cos φ + y s R s i n φ d φ d Ѳ Where X s , Y s , Z s and R are the coordinates of the points located on the surface of the catalytic films and the radius of the cylinder supporting the sample (Fig. 1). Finally, the q s u p x/y components (see Fig. S1; Eq. (3)) can be determined using q n and a radiation balance, which considers the main optical (Transmittance, Fi, and Reflectance, Ri) events occurring in all components of the reactor placed between the emission source and catalyst, i.e. glass and reaction media, as well on the catalytic film. (3) q s u p x , y = f q n , F i , R i ; i = c a t a l y s t , g l a s s , r e a c t i o n m e d i a A detailed description of the mathematical formulation to provide q s u p as a function of q n (Eq. (2)) and the transmittance/reflectance optical measurements for each component of our reactor system can be found elsewhere [67,68]. 2.4.2 Quantum efficiency Quantum efficiency values ( ƞ q ) were determined using Eq. (4) [54]. This work presents the determination of the true quantum efficiency according to the IUPAC recommendation dividing the reaction rate (r: mol m−2 s-1) by the superficial rate of photon absorption ( e a , s : Einstein m−2 s-1). The calculation procedure details were described previously in Subsection 2.4.1. (4) ƞ q ( % ) = 100 × r e a , s 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization results Fig. 1 displays the XRD patterns of the g-C3N4 reference and the M/g-C3N4 samples. All patterns show the typical profile of the graphitic g-C3N4 layered structure, dominated by the interlayer-stacking (002) reflection. Additionally, the [100] reflection, related to the intralayer structural packing motif of tri-s-triazine units, is detected in all samples at around 13.1 degrees [8,9,22]. Absence of appreciable differences between the support and the samples can be noted. This suggests that the impregnation procedure of the M-containing species does not alter the support to a large degree. This is further corroborated by the morphological observables presented in Table 1 . In particular, the BET area of the support is 15.9 m2 g−1 while those of the samples oscillate between 15.3 and 13.2 m2 g−1. So, a small decrease of surface area would take place and is likely attributable to a limited occlusion of the pores of the carbon nitride. This blocking effect is mostly detectable in the reduced pore volume of the samples compared with the bare carbon nitride. In spite of it, the average pore size is in the 16−20 nm range for all samples (Table 1), indicating a limited differential effect in the adsorption of the reactants. Low and medium magnified micrographs of the Zn/g-C3N4 material are presented in Fig. 2 . They are representative for all materials and show the typical laminar morphology of the support. The M-containing phases are not detected in the micrographs. In fact, as shown in Fig. S2, such entities were not detected using electron diffraction. This strongly indicates that they have an amorphous or poorly crystallized character in all cases. The physico-chemical properties of the support were also analyzed using XPS. Fig. 3 displays an example of the C 1s and N 1s XPS regions obtained for the support and the samples. All samples show the same C 1s and N 1s XPS spectra without changes (within experimental error) in peak(s) position and intensity (see Fig. S3). Fitting of carbon and nitrogen species has been shown previously to require three (main) different components in each case [6,30,69,73]. Fig. 3 shows the C 1s XPS peak has contributions from the C-C signal (which may have a contribution for spurious entities besides that of the main component of the sample) as well as two contributions located at higher binding energy and related to bridging carbons between aromatic moieties (C3-N) or at the aromatic rings (N-C-N). Similarly, the fitting of the N 1s XPS spectrum displayed in Fig. 3 points out contributions from the above mentioned C3-N and N-C-N species as well as N-H and CN pi-excitation moieties [6,69,70]. In short, the analysis of the C 1s and N 1s XPS regions provided evidence for the absence changes between the g-C3N4 support previously published [30] and all the M/g-C3N4 samples here analyzed. STEM-XEDS (scanning transmission electron microscopy with X-ray energy dispersive spectrometry) was used to obtain an initial assessment of the dispersion of the supported phases. Fig. 4 displays results for two representative samples. As can be seen, the M-containing phases are observed in the zones of the micrographs where there is larger accumulation of the support (this is observed both at the STEM micrographs as well as comparing N and Mn+ XEDS maps). In general, the M-containing entities are homogeneously distributed, with rather limited differences between the samples. Due to the amorphous nature of the phases (demonstrated by electron diffraction) high resolution microscopy images do not provide significant information about the supported components. XPS and XANES can nevertheless render information about the chemical nature of the M-containing entities located at the surface of the carbon nitride component. Fig. 5 contains XPS plots for all M/g-C3N4 samples while Table 2 summarizes the peak binding energies as well as corresponding assignments. Fig. 6 shows the corresponding M cation K-edge XANES spectra. This technique allows analyzing the (symmetry projected) valence density of states and is more sensitive than XPS to specific details of the chemical bond between the metals and the anions included in the oxo-hydroxide species [71]. The combination of both techniques renders complete information to characterizing the local environment of M cations from both structural and electronic perspectives. In addition, XPS can render information about the dispersion state of the M-containing phases. Table 3 collects information relative to the M/(C + N) atomic ratios experimentally measured using XPS, which are confronted with values of the same observable measured with the help of ICP-AES. Due to the relatively similar amount of M atoms in the samples, this comparison renders an estimation of the relative (among the series of samples) aggregation of the M-containing phases. From XPS ratios it is observed that the Cu phase is aggregated if compared with Ni, Zn and Mn entities. Differences among catalysts can become more evident through the adimensional ratio between the two M/(C + N) atomic ratios presented in Table 3. Fixing an arbitrary value of 1 to the ratio of the solid having higher dispersion (Mn), values of 0.99 (Zn), 0.82 (Ni) and 0.39 (Cu) were obtained. Although this ratio does not provide any measurement of the dispersion or aggregation state, allows to (roughly) analyzing the relative aggregation state among samples, indicating that Mn, Zn and Ni components present relatively similar dispersion while Cu presents a lower dispersion. Starting with the structural and electronic analysis of Ni in the Ni/g-C3N4 sample, we observed a Ni 2p3/2 XPS peak position at 855.7 eV, well above that of NiO and characteristic of Ni(OH)2 species [72]. This species has been previously detected on Ni-containing g-C3N4 based samples [73]. The Ni/g-C3N4 sample XANES spectra is presented in Fig. 6 (panel a) together with the NiO and Ni(OH)2 reference spectra. The edge position of all three solids is the same, allowing inferring that Ni has a Ni(II) oxidation state. The pre-edge peak of the powder materials (see the inset) is located at the same position than the Ni(OH)2 reference but with higher intensity and differs from the one of NiO. In agreement with XPS, this fact suggests that the local order is similar to the Ni(OH)2 reference. The mentioned pre-edge corresponds to the ls core level excitation to bound unoccupied p/d-states near the Fermi level. The single pre-peak of Ni(II) species occurs because the (3d lower energy) t2g orbital is fully occupied when the number of 3d-electron number is above six [74]. The lower intensity of pre-peak in the Ni(OH)2 reference would thus indicate a larger occupation of the Ni 3d states with respect to the catalysts. Besides, the larger width of this pre-edge peak in the Ni(OH)2 reference with respect to the Ni/g-C3N4 sample would indicate a greater gap between t2 and e states. The described intensity and width variations have been jointly interpreted as a reduction of Ni (local) centrosymmetry, connected with larger structural distortions with respect to the reference [74,75]. For the Cu/g-C3N4 sample, the near absence of the satellite peak in the XPS spectrum (Fig. 5) indicates the absence of Cu(II) species [72]. A single Cu 2p3/2 contribution at 931.9 eV is observed. This single species can be ascribed to an oxidized Cu(I) species. For the Cu/g-C3N4 sample, the comparison of the XANES spectrum with the Cu2O reference with equal edge position(s) indicates in fact that the copper cation in the sample is in a Cu(I) state (Fig. 6, panel b). Considering the pre-edge peak, a single well defined pre-peak at 8983–8984 eV is another fingerprint of the Cu(I) oxidation state of the material [71,74]. For the cuprite structure, C u 2 2 [ O t ] b , with a not linear Cu–O linkage, or O–Cu–O angle < 180°, the pre-edge intensity strongly depends of the distance and the angular Cu–O linkage [76]. Thus the larger pre-edge intensity of our system with respect to the (linear O-Cu-O) Cu2O system indicates distortion on both distances and angles. Moreover, the first resonance of the continuum (the so called white line) splits into two with respect to the Cu2O reference, indicating again changes in 3d density and/or local geometry around Cu cations [77]. So, our amorphous Cu2Ox-type clusters have a significant variation in local geometry with respect to the (crystalline) Cu2O reference material. This detailed electronic/structural information cannot be achieved using exclusively XPS. For the Zn/g-C3N4 sample XPS detected a single contribution with a Zn 2p3/2 binding energy of 1022.1 eV. This peak is characteristic of Zn(II) type species but shifts to slightly higher energy with respect to the ZnO reference [72]. This has been previously attributed to the interaction with the carbon nitride component [78]. In the case of the Zn/g-C3N4 sample, the comparison with the ZnO reference XANES spectrum presented in Fig. 6 (panel c) also indicates the Zn(II) oxidation state of the cation in the catalysts. The completion of the 3d electronic shell in Zn triggers the absence of pre-edge peaks [71,74]. The shape of the catalyst spectrum shows clear differences with the ZnO reference indicating a strongly modified local environment. Importantly, the white line shape is clearly different than the one characteristic of a pure oxidic environment. In biological systems, it has been reported that Zn first shell distances and coordination can be affected by the O/N ratio [79,80]. In particular ref. [80] shows XANES spectra similar to that obtained by us. This fact would suggest that the Zn-N interaction (N atoms coming from the g-C3N4 support) is present in the cation first coordination shell. We tested such a hypothesis by performing a theoretical calculation of the XANES spectrum corresponding to an intermolecular zinc–nitrogen coordinated species that contains four Zn-N bonds at first shell [81]. As shown in the supporting information (Fig. S4), the continuum resonances of the Zn/g-C3N4 sample and the “Zn-N” reference display nearly identical energy positions, providing support to conclude the dominant presence of N at the cation neighborhood. We note that the theoretical simulation of a XANES spectrum is still an open research field but: i) the important experimental differences of the Zn/g-C3N4 sample with the ZnO reference (particularly the while line shape and position) are not related to a size effect [82]; and ii) according to the literature, are strongly indicative of the presence of a different (than oxygen) first neighbor atom [83]. So, the XANES shape of the Zn/g-C3N4 sample appears only compatible (strong similitude in white line shape) with the presence of nitrogen in XANES spectra of biological systems [79,80]. Because XANES shows that the Zn/g-C3N4 sample is the only one showing potential interaction with the support (differences in the XANES spectra with the ZnO reference are not explained by size or any local distortion effects presented in pure oxide/hydroxide phases, as occur with the other cations here studied), we complete the structural characterization of this sample using EXAFS. Fig. 7 contains plots of the Fourier Transform of the EXAFS signals for the sample and the ZnO reference. The corresponding fitting results are summarized in Table 4 . This Table compares the coordination distance and number for the four first shells of the oxide reference and the sample. The first thing that is observed is the notorious decrease in the number of Zn neighbors (3rd and 4th shells). For the bare ZnO-oxide, there are twelve neighbors, while ca. 3.1 neighbors are obtained in the best fit for the EXAFS-signal of the sample. The similitude with the bare oxide is not a surprise as ZnOxNy materials have shown to maintain the wurtzite-type local structure around Zn [84,85]. Concerning the Zn-O/N shell, Zn is coordinated with ca. 3.9 O/N at an average distance of 1.89 Å in the sample vs. 4 O at 1.92 Å for the ZnO reference, a fact again compatible with the presence of nitrogen [79,80]. We note that cannot distinguish between O and N scatterers (atoms with atomic number differing in 1 unit, see ref. 86] using EXAFS. Nevertheless, the combination of XPS/XANES/EXAFS provides a complete analysis of the point. While EXAFS allows to inferring the possible dominant substitutional (not interstitial) position of heteroatoms at the anion sublattice of a ZnOxNy powder [84,85], XPS discards the presence of a nitride type compound but demonstrates important differences with a pure oxidic environment [87,88]. So, the presence of N atoms at Zn first shell (suggested by both XPS and XANES) would occur within a wurtzite-type local structure. EXAFS fitting shows on the other hand that the sample has a rather limited size with a limited Zn-O(N)-Zn coordination indicating that the cluster would have (according to a wurtzite-type local order) an average size of ca. 1 nm. The structure of the Zn-containing oxynitride entities is unique among our samples and has not been identified previously in the literature of g-C3N4 based samples. To analyze of Mn chemical state we make an analysis of the 2p/3p/3 s XPS peaks [39,89,90]. As shown by the seminal work of Ilton et al. [91], both the complexity of the peak (overlapping of the mutiplet structure corresponding to the different Mn oxidation states, as detailed also by other authors, see for example, ref. [92] and the effects of the reduction degree can be minimized while studying the 3 s peak and thus Fig. 5 displays this peak. The multiplet structure of the electronic transition is described in the three contributions presented in Fig. 5 [91]. A Mn(IV) state can be deduced by the binding energy presented in Table 2. The Mn electronic properties are further analyzed here using XANES. Panel d of Fig. 4 shows the XANES spectrum of the Mn/gC3N4 sample. It displays a nearly identical shape to the alpha (Ramsdellite) MnO2 reference indicating the dominant Mn(IV) oxidation and a local geometry relatively close to the reference. The local environment of Mn in Ramsdellite is octahedral Oh [74,93]. The inset of Fig. 6 (panel d) displays the isolated pre-peak for the sample and the reference. For Ramsdellite-MnO2, the pre-peak has two centroids, at 6540.1 eV and at 6541.91 eV, and the intensity (i.e. the area) is greater than the intensity of the pre-peak for the Mn/g-C3N4. We can also note the inversion of the intensities of the centroids for MnOx-gC3N4 with respect to Ramsdellite-MnO2. The difference in energy between both centroids corresponds to the crystal field splitting of d orbitals. For Oh -symmetry, the lowest energy position is assigned to t2g and the highest is assigned to eg orbitals. In this way, we observe that the t2g -orbitals are more unoccupied than the eg -orbitals for Mn/g-C3N4, and on average there is less 3d-electronic probability (i.e. larger 3d occupancy) of transition for Mn/g-C3N4 than for the Ramsdellite reference. For oxide-supported Mn-containing materials, this fact has been previously observed and can be attributed to an effect of the nanostructure [89]. On the other hand, due to a minimal difference in the white line, it can be inferred that there are more 4p unoccupied density in the sample than in the oxide. Thus the relatively modest variation of local symmetry between the two solids would indicate a 3d-4p rehybridation in the sample with respect to the reference, transferring charge for the 4p to the 3d subband. This is likely a response to lower metal-oxygen Pauli repulsion with respect to the reference. To end up the physico-chemical characterization of the catalysts, we examined the optical properties of the samples using UV–vis spectroscopy. Fig. S5 includes the spectra for the samples and the g-C3N4 support. The spectra are dominated by the support features and the corresponding band gap values are presented in Table 1. These values are calculated considering the materials indirect band gap semiconductors, as is the case of bulk g-C3N4 [6,94]. A constant value of 2.7 eV is obtained for all samples, indicating (again) the near null modification of the support by effect of the M-containing precursor incorporation. In summary, the g-C3N4 support suffers rather limited modification by the surface deposition of M-containing entities. The almost constancy in physico-chemical properties concerns the similar morphological (BET area), structural (XRD), and electronic (UV–vis; band gap) observables encountered through the series of samples. The M-containing entities are essentially amorphous (or poorly crystallized) in nature and are accommodated in the pore structure of the carbon nitride component. Among M-containing species we observed similar (high) dispersion values for Ni, Zn and Mn but Cu showed a significantly lower value. The nearly amorphous Ni has a local order resembling that of the pure beta phase of the Ni (II) hydroxide while Cu and Mn display (nearly amorphous) pure oxidic forms. Cu has a Cu(I) oxidation state with a unique local order while Mn displays a Mn(IV) oxidation state. Finally, Zn appears in a Zn(II) oxidation state but the results show the formation of poorly crystallized, nanostructured (ca. 1 nm) oxy-nitride particles, with active participation of nitrogen atoms from the support. The intereaction through the sharing of N atoms takes place at the interface between the components. This is suggested by the measure of the strain of the carbon nitride component using XRD. Table S2 demonstrates the negigible differences between the reference and the catalysts, indicating the (practical) absence of Mn+ (including Zn) ions at the bulk of the carbon nitride component. 3.2 Photocatalytic quantum efficiency for toluene degradation: measurement and interpretation The performance of the samples in the toluene photo-oxidation reaction was in first place analyzed through the measurement of the reaction rate and the selectivity of the process. Such data sets are presented in Fig. 8 both under UV and Sunlight-type illumination conditions. The rates are ordered in an increasing trend to facilitate the visualization. So, we observe that Cu-containing entities decrease the rate of the bare support for all illumination conditions tested in this work. Mn and Ni containing entities have a relatively minor effect in the reaction rate while Zn significantly boosts activity under both illumination conditions. The activity of the materials is not comparable (near 5 times lower as measured using the same reaction set-up) with that of the Titania P25 reference under UV but is significantly larger under Sunlight-type owning to the almost null performance presented by this titania sample [53,95]. As shown in previous publications, toluene photo-oxidation has been carried out with Mn/g-C3N4 materials, which presented slightly lower or similar rate values (ratios from 0.5 to 1) to those here reported [44,96]. To our knowledge, there are no literature reports using the other M/g-C3N4 systems for toluene photo-oxidation. Nevertheless, Mn/g-C3N4 materials were used for carbon dioxide photo-reduction, with an enhancement factor of ca. 3 with respect to the bare support [34]. Similarly, the beta nickel hydroxide phase supported on g-C3N4 has been tested in hydrogen and oxygen evolution with the help of sacrificial agents. In this case, an increase of ca. 2.5 times with respect to the reaction rate of the bare support was detected for both reactions [73]. The selectivity of the toluene degradation has been examined previously only in the case of the Mn-containing materials [44]. The g-C3N4 support shows the production of carbon dioxide as complete mineralization product and benzaldehyde as partial oxidation product. CO2 dominates under UV while under Sunlight-type illumination both products are nearly equally formed. This roughly agrees with previous reports [44]. Nevertheless, in presence of all M-containing species we observe a modest increase of the selectivity to benzaldehyde irrespective of the illumination conditions. Benzaldehyde production reaches its maximum, near 60 % of selectivity under both illumination conditions for the Zn/g-C3N4 catalysts. In order to compare the catalytic output of the M/g-C3N4 samples in quantitative basis we calculated the quantum efficiency for the toluene photo-oxidation using the IUPAC formulation of the observable [54]. Such formulation (Eq. (12)) requires the calculation of the local superficial rate of photon absorption, e a , s . The obtaining of the e a , s observable considers, according to Fig. S1, a cylindrical geometry and two independent geometrical variables. The local superficial rate of photon absorption observable across the corresponding two dimension reaction coordinates are presented in Fig. S6 under all (UV and sunlight-type) illumination conditions tested in the study. The panels of Fig. S6 indicate the same geometrical behavior for all samples under study and thus differences between samples can be presented by a single number, the average value of e a , s . Calculated values of the toluene photo-oxidation quantum efficiency using this procedure are displayed in Fig. 9 for the two illumination sources used in the study. As shown in Fig. 9, efficiency values are in the ca. 1.0–2.0 × 10−4 interval for our samples. Maximum values of ca. 2.0 and 1.6 × 10−4 for, respectively, UV and Sunlight-type illumination are obtained for the Zn/g-C3N4 sample. These values imply enhancement factors of 1.8 and 1.45 with respect to the support for, respectively, UV and Sunlight-type illumination. As previously discussed, a value for the enhancement factor near 1.5–2 is in line with previous reports for the most active M/g-C3N4 materials tested in toluene photo-oxidation [44,96] as well as other photo-reactions [34,73]. On the other hand, it is interesting to remark the relatively weak dependence on illumination wavelength presented by the efficiency values obtained for the g-C3N4 support and most of the M/g-C3N4 samples. We also tested the stability of the Zn/g-C3N4 material in a long run (72 h of time on stream) without appreciable change in catalytic behavior as demonstrated by efficiency and selectivity observables collected in Table S1. To provide insights into the physical origin of the enhancement of activity of the Zn/g-C3N4 material with respect to the bare support, we carried out a photoluminescence study (Fig. 10 ). Under a 365 nm light excitation, the g-C3N4 reference shows a broad, featureless peak at ca. 490 nm [7,8]. The M/g-C3N4 catalysts present rather similar spectra but with decreasing overall intensity. A similar situation is observed when the samples are excited with a 425 nm wavelength. Under visible excitation we observe a similar decay than under UV and an intensity behavior throughout the samples of our series also mimics the previous case. EPR was also used to shed light into the charge handling capability of the samples and the effect of this phenomenon on photoactivity. Specifically, the generation of the reactive oxygen species (ROS) in selected samples under illumination was investigated by EPR spin trapping technique, using the 5,5-dimethyl-l-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) as a spin trap molecule. The hydroxyl (OH ) and superoxide (O2 −) radical formation was observed by monitoring of the DMPO-OH and DMPO-O2- adducts. These are the two most common radical formed in photoactive samples by holes and electrons reaching the surface of the materials. Hydroxyl radicals are primary formed from holes although can be also formed from electrons in a multi(electron) process. In contrast, superoxide radicals are exclusively formed from electrons and are precursor species of hydroxyl-type radicals when the latter is formed from electron species [1,2]. As shown in the EPR spectra displayed in Fig. 11 A for the Zn/g-C3N4 system suspended in water, immediately after the UV irradiation started a typical 4-peaks signal attributed to the formation of a DMPO-OH adduct. The Zn/g-C3N4 catalyst exemplifies the EPR signals obtained with all samples. This EPR signal displays (peak) intensities of 1:2:2:1 and spin Hamiltonian parameters: aNO = 14.9 G, aH = 14.9 G; g = 2.0056 [97–99]. The intensity of the DMPO-OH signal increases with UV irradiation time. The accumulation of DMPO-OH radical adducts grows continuously for all samples but such radicals have a limited stability and a maximum concentration as a function of time is always detected (panel A of Fig. 11). The latter is an effect of multiple additions, within consecutive reactions, of OH radicals to DMPO molecules to yield diamagnetic species [22,99,100]. Under UV radiation, the sample Zn/g-C3N4 suspended in methanol (a well-known molecule used as an efficient scavenger of photogenerated holes) renders a typical 6-broad-peaks EPR signal attributed to the DMPO-O2 − adduct (Fig. 11B). The DMPO-superoxide adduct signal is characterized by hyperfine coupling constants: aNO = 13.76; aH β = 9.63; aH γ = 1.32 (symbols β and γ denote the position of the interacting hydrogen nuclei) and a g-value of 2.0057 [101,102]. The intensity of DMPO-O2 − signal also increases with UV-irradiation time and evolves in a similar way than the DMPO-OH adduct. So, due to the undesired effect of multiple additions, comparison of radical species formation rates are here quantitatively analyzed using the initial formation rate measured by the slopes presented in Fig. S7 for UV illumination. Values of the initial rates for both UV and sunlight-type illumination are summarized in Table S3. We will combine the information coming from photoluminescence and EPR studies to interpret the catalytic behavior of the samples. As the EPR results measured the charge carrier species able to generate chemistry at surfaces (a step forward in the reaction mechanism with respect to photoluminescence), we also presented a correlation plot of EPR results and the quantum efficiency observable in Fig. 12 . The Cu/g-C3N4 sample shows a photoluminescence (intensity) behavior intermediate between the support and the rest of samples and this may have an effect on photoactivity. EPR results (Table S3; Fig. 12) indicates that presence of Cu(I) oxide type clusters do not influence significantly the generation of hydroxyl and superoxide radicals with respect to the dominant phase of the catalyst, the g-C3N4. The band diagram presented in Scheme 1 for the components of the M/g-C3N4 solids uses the band gap values reported in the literature [103]. Scheme 1 can help to rationalize the relatively poor performance of this material. Note that the different Cu(I)-containing oxide materials present a maximum position of the valence band as well as band gap values with relatively insensibility to the O-Cu-O angle [103–105]. The band positions of the Mn+ component would thus suggest that the copper-containing phase would donate electrons to the carbon nitride component if excited (particularly under visible radiation, which excites the Cu component). Apparently such electrons do not help to increase the activity but is somehow detrimental for the Cu case. Thus, the mild effect of Cu in charge recombination (as measured by photoluminescence), and the limited radical formation capability of the sample (as measured with respect to the g-C3N4 reference using EPR) under all illumination conditions tested justify the adverse effect in toluene photo-oxidation activity and likely indicate that low activity may be primarily influenced by the poor dispersion of the oxidic Cu cluster. An inefficient interface interaction is thus a direct consequence of the metal poor dispersion. Photoluminescence (Fig. 10) and EPR results (Table S3; Fig. 12) indicates that the here detected Ni hydroxide-type phase has an important effect in recombination (Fig. 10) which is mainly reflected by a significant enhancement in superoxide radicals (Table S3; Fig. 12). This is in qualitative agreement with Scheme 1 which shows that the interaction between these two phases would withdraw electrons from the Ni hydroxide phase under UV and (to a lesser extent) sunlight-type excitation. Such an effect has however a limited effect on quantum efficiency (Fig. 12). This can be rationalized considering that the toluene oxidation would require the use of hydroxyl-type radicals, the most energetic radical species [29,106]. The presence of a Ramsdellite type Mn oxide phase would produce also a unique effect in charge handling for the Mn/g-C3N4 catalyst according to Scheme 1. EPR results can provide information to interpret the contact between the existent phases. Scheme 1 considers a pure Mn(IV) oxide phase, as demonstrated by XANES spectroscopy. So, according to Scheme 1 (which includes band positions and gap values), under UV and sunlight-type illumination (cut off at around 900 nm) only the carbon nitride component is excited and an efficient charge carrier separation occurs. Nevertheless, this decreases the number of electrons to generate superoxide radical species and drives to relatively limited variations of hole formed species (Table S3; Fig. 12). The effect of an efficient charge separation by contact between components of the catalysts is also detected in the photoluminescence experiments (Fig. 10). Thus, our photoluminescence and EPR data are fully consistent with the presence of an oxidic Mn(IV) phase and the situation depicted in Scheme 1. This leads to electron withdrawal from the carbon nitride component and a rather modest increase of hydroxyl radicals. As mentioned, the last charge carrier species is required to photo-oxidize toluene [29,106] and justify the relatively modest yet positive effect in photoactivity (Fig. 12). To end up the discussion we can note that the minimum photoluminescence intensity in Fig. 10 corresponds, irrespective of the illumination conditions, to the Zn/g-C3N4 catalyst, the sample displaying maximum activity. As minimum photoluminescence intensity without other spectral changes from the support can be ascribed to a decrease in charge carrier recombination, we may consider that the effect in the recombination of charge after illumination has an important impact in the activity of the most active catalyst. This is also supported by the EPR (Table S3; Fig. 12) results which showed that this catalyst produces the larger amount of hydroxyl type radicals among our samples. Of course, the Zn-containing phase itself (contrarily to the other Mn+ phases here used) can contribute significantly to this point [1]. Photoluminescence and EPR results support Scheme 1 in terms of the unique effects (among our samples) triggered by the physical contact between ZnOxNy and g-C3N4 components. The presence of nitrogen in the Zn-containing phase (ZnOxNy) will not modify importantly the band gap. The electronic changes triggered by nitrogen (at least for modest oxygen substitution to main the zinc oxide wurtzite structure according to our analysis) do not alter significantly the picture (band positions) presented in Scheme 1. In the zinc oxide, nitrogen incorporation is supposed to produce gap states near the valence band [1,107]. Thus, under UV excitation (in this system taking place both components) an effective separation of charge can occur. Under sunlight-type excitation g-C3N4 has a significantly larger absorption than the Zn-containing phase and would have a dominant contribution to charge carrier formation. In any case, EPR results (Table S3; Fig. 12) show that charge carrier separation facilitates the creation of hydroxyl radical and decreases the formation of superoxide radicals with respect to the dominant carbon nitride component under all illumination conditions tested. This would indicate that withdrawal of electrons from the carbon nitride component produces a (modest) decrease of superoxide radicals and that hydroxyl radicals can be here (for this sample) created from both holes and electrons. The positive catalytic effect of Zn and, to lower extent, Mn, and the negative effect of Cu and Ni are essentially driven by the charge separation process occurring (under both illumination sources) by the contact betweem the two components of the catalysts and the need of hydroxyl-related radicals for oxidizing efficienctly toluene. Fig. 12 illustrates such a correlation, providing a quantitative measure of the rate of formation of radical species and their influence in the reaction rate. The importance of the hydroxyl radical species (the more oxidizing radical species) for toluene has been previously observed in titania-based materials [29,106], and this seems also the case of carbon nitride based materials, although with our composite systems hydroxyl radicals are formed from both electrons and (in specific cases, typically Zn) holes. 4 Conclusions In this work we deposited “oxidized” M-containing entities onto a g-C3N4 support. After calcination of the precursors, the corresponding systems display a variety of chemical situations for the amorphous-like M-containing entities while the support remains essentially unaltered. Absence of doping or incorporation of M cations to the bulk of the carbon nitride network is noted for all systems. Ni is present in a beta Ni(II) hydroxide-type local environment. Cu is in a Cu(I) oxidic-type local environment typically of cuprite structures. Zn shows a significant interaction with the support, displaying a Zn(II) oxynitride-type local environment with some nitrogen atoms directly coming and shared with the support. This leads to small structures of ca. 1 nm of diameter. Finally, Mn displays a slight modified Mn(IV) oxidic-type local environment with respect to the alpha MnO2 structure. All materials, except the Cu-containing one, show the presence of highly dispersed entities over the g-C3N4 support. The M/g-C3N4 materials display higher activity than the well-known P25 TiO2 reference under sunlight operation and can show improved toluene photo-oxidation performance with respect to the bare support under UV and Sunlight-type illumination conditions. Specifically, the Cu-containing material displays lower quantum efficiency than the bare support due to a combination of the hole withdrawal from the main component and the inefficient contact between the components of the system. Ni and Mn-containing samples show essentially the same or slightly higher efficiency of that of the bare g-C3N4 while the Zn-containing catalyst display efficiency enhancement factors of 1.8 and 1.45 with respect to the support for, respectively, UV and Sunlight-type illumination. The physico-chemical characterization as well as an analysis of the generation and fate (including recombination) of charge carrier species using photoluminescence and EPR indicates that optimum activity would be intimately linked with the strong interface interaction of the two components in the Zn/g-C3N4 material, which shares N atoms between them. Intimate contact between components would thus allow efficient charge separation and decreases recombination under UV and visible light illumination conditions, with subsequent enhancement of the formation of the hydroxyl radical responsible for the pollutant degradation. coredata.dc:description: In this work we analyze the photocatalytic performance of Mn+ (MCu, Ni, Zn, Mn) - g-C3N4 materials in toluene photo-oxidation under UV and Sunlight-type illumination conditions. The characterization of the solids showed that Cu and Mn containing samples have an oxide type environment, while Ni has a hydroxide type and Zn shows an oxynitride type local order. The photo-activity of the samples under UV and sunlight excitation(s) was evaluated in terms of activity and selectivity, and the subsequent calculation of the quantum efficiency. Optimum activity was obtained with the Zn-containing catalyst. The charge carrier(s) handling and fate through interfaces and recombination was measured and correlated with the structural characterization of the solids. This indicates that the interface contact between the Zn oxynitride and carbon nitride components has significant influence in charge carrier processes and it is at the core of the good photocatalytic properties owned by this sample.
coredata.dc:title: Sunlight active g-C3N4-based Mn+ (MCu, Ni, Zn, Mn) – promoted catalysts: Sharing of nitrogen atoms as a door for optimizing photo-activity
